testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Early Britain & Roman Era
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering Stone Age, Bronze Age, Iron Age, and Roman Britain periods including key events, people, and cultural developments.

questions.stem: Who were the first people to arrive in Britain?
questions.explanation: The first people to arrive in Britain were hunter-gatherers during the Stone Age, around 10,000 years ago.

questions.stem: Stonehenge was built during which period?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge was built during the Stone Age, around 5,000 years ago. It's one of the most famous prehistoric monuments in the world.

questions.stem: The Bronze Age people were the first to work with metal.
questions.explanation: True. Bronze Age people (around 4,000 years ago) were the first to work with metals, particularly bronze made from copper and tin.

questions.stem: What did Iron Age people build for protection?
questions.explanation: Iron Age people built hill forts for protection. These were fortified settlements built on high ground, often surrounded by ditches and walls.

questions.stem: Which language did the Celts speak?
questions.explanation: The Celts spoke Celtic languages. Parts of these languages still survive today in Welsh, Scottish Gaelic, and Irish Gaelic.

questions.stem: In which year did the Romans first invade Britain?
questions.explanation: Julius Caesar first invaded Britain in 55 BC, though the successful Roman conquest began in 43 AD under Emperor Claudius.

questions.stem: Who led the successful Roman invasion of Britain in 43 AD?
questions.explanation: Emperor Claudius led the successful Roman invasion of Britain in 43 AD, establishing Roman rule that lasted nearly 400 years.

questions.stem: What was Boudicca famous for?

options.label: Leading a rebellion against the Romans

questions.explanation: Boudicca was the queen of the Iceni tribe who led a major uprising against Roman rule in 60-61 AD.

questions.stem: Which of these were built by the Romans in Britain?
questions.explanation: Romans built extensive road networks, public baths, and defensive walls (like Hadrian's Wall). Stone circles were built much earlier by prehistoric peoples.

questions.stem: Hadrian's Wall was built to keep out which people?
questions.explanation: Hadrian's Wall was built around 122 AD to keep out the Picts and other tribes from Scotland.

questions.stem: The Romans remained in Britain for about 400 years.
questions.explanation: True. The Romans occupied Britain from 43 AD to around 410 AD, approximately 400 years.

questions.stem: What did the Romans introduce to Britain?
questions.explanation: Romans introduced new plants and animals, the calendar system, and coins. The English language developed later from Anglo-Saxon.

questions.stem: Where can you see Roman remains today?
questions.explanation: You can see Roman remains in many places including Bath (Roman baths), St Albans, Chester, and York.

questions.stem: When did the Romans leave Britain?
questions.explanation: The Romans left Britain around 410 AD when they withdrew their armies to defend other parts of the Empire.

questions.stem: The Romans brought Christianity to Britain.
questions.explanation: True. Christianity came to Britain during the Roman period, though it became more widespread after the Romans left.

questions.stem: What was the Roman name for London?
questions.explanation: The Roman name for London was Londinium, which became an important trading centre.

questions.stem: The Celts were skilled in which activities?
questions.explanation: Celts were skilled metalworkers, cloth makers, and pottery makers. Road building was a Roman specialty.

questions.stem: Skara Brae is located in which part of the UK?
questions.explanation: Skara Brae is a well-preserved Stone Age village in Orkney, Scotland, dating from around 5,000 years ago.

questions.stem: The Druids were Celtic priests and teachers.
questions.explanation: True. Druids were Celtic priests who also acted as teachers, judges, and doctors in Celtic society.

questions.stem: What was woad used for by the ancient Britons?
questions.explanation: Woad was a blue dye used by ancient Britons to paint their bodies, particularly during battles.

questions.stem: Roman soldiers were organized into units called:
questions.explanation: Roman soldiers were organized into legions, each containing about 5,000-6,000 men.

questions.stem: The Romans built the first towns in Britain.
questions.explanation: True. While there were settlements before, the Romans built the first proper towns with planned streets, public buildings, and amenities.

questions.stem: Which metals did Bronze Age people mix to make bronze?
questions.explanation: Bronze is made by mixing copper and tin. This was a major technological advancement of the Bronze Age.

questions.stem: Maiden Castle is an example of what type of prehistoric structure?
questions.explanation: Maiden Castle in Dorset is one of the largest and most complex Iron Age hill forts in Europe.
